Something Special or Unique: It is a high nectar producer, and grows in a range of soils.  Native Americans applied it to open wounds, and wildlife loves the proteinaceous seeds.  This legume (or pea-family plant) fixes nitrogen in the soil.  It is drought resistant and native to North America.  Dalea is a superfood for the Rusty-Patched Bumblebee, which is listed as endangered.  It is also a host plant for the larvae of the Dogface Sulphur (common in New York) and Reakirt's Blue.  This plant blooms heavily for four weeks in June and continues to bloom sporadically until September.  It needs support in its first year because it uses most of its energy developing a long taproot (a mature plant's taproot will be 5.5-6 feet) which will later allow it to become drought resistant.  Leaves can be used for tea, and roots are palatable.

Habit: Height: 12” (24” with flower stalk), Spread: 12”-24”, Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Very long blooming, low maintenance, low water requirement second year.  Native to New York.  Rabbits and deer nibble in spring, but plants recover.
Images: Rudbeckia fulgida var. sullivantii:Rudbeckia fulgida var. sullivantii Seedling

Soil Type: Any soil, but must be well draining; drought resistant
When to Divide: Rosettes can be removed in early spring
Habit: Height: 18”, Spread: 18”, Clumping
Long Lived or Short Lived: 3 years in soggy ground or shade; otherwise very long lived
Something Special or Unique: Difficult to grow from seed.  Will flower late first year, and return strong next year. Remove spent flowers to promote reblooming

Where to Grow: Full to part sun.  Does not tolerate shade.
Soil Type: Tolerates sandy, medium, clay soils with little nutrition.  Does not like to be fertilized, drought tolerant, will tolerate moist soil.
When to Divide: Divide clumps in spring by gently teasing apart roots
Habit: Height:  24" Spread:  12" Clumping
Maturity Rate: Blooms first year at the end of the season.
Something Special or Unique: Young leaves are excellent in salads and soups.  Do not eat during pregnancy.  Grows well with Lamb's Ears

Soil Type: Well-draining, normal to sandy, infertile soil; drought tolerant
Habit: Height:  6-8” (8” with flower stalk) Spread:  12” Clumping.
Long Lived or Short Lived: Long lived; short lived in soggy soil
Something Special or Unique: Sheer after flowering to tidy; evergreen, good ground cover

Soil Type: Will grow in clay soils, but must be well-draining.  Drought resistant once established.  Needs care for first two years.
When to Divide: Do not divide.  Collect seeds, refrigerate until February, soak with warm (100F) water for 24 hours and start indoors.  Transplant outdoors when 4-6" high.
Habit: Height:  12" Spread:  12" Habit:  Hairy, fluffy clumps.
Something Special or Unique: Roots are medicinal.  Do not cut back in fall, cut back in spring instead.  Mulching is recommended for Zones 4 and 5

Soil Type: Well draining soil, drought resistant, no fertilizer needed, water only when soil is chalky dry
Habit: Height: 4”, Spread: Sprawling
Something Special or Unique: Evergreen, good in containers, rock walls, crevasses, as groundcover; good for draping over edges of pots, rocks or steep hillsides
Images: Sedum forsterianum 'Oracle':Sedum sexangulare:Sedum spurium 'Coccineum':Sedum spurium 'Summer Glory'

Soil Type: Well-draining soil; drought resistant, no fertilizer needed, water only when soil is chalky dry
Habit: Height: 4”, Spread: Sprawling
Something Special or Unique: Evergreen, good in containers, rock walls, crevasses, as groundcover; good for draping over edges of pots, rocks or steep hillsides

Soil Type: Dry soil, low fertility, drought resistant
When to Divide: Early spring; when rosette has several small roots, cut rosette free with scissors
Habit: Height: 4"-6” (18” with flower stalk) Spread: 6-12” Spreading; produces rosettes
Something Special or Unique: Tolerates black walnut trees

Soil Type: Moist but well-draining, does not like water-logged winter soils
When to Divide: Divide spreading clumps in spring; when rosette has several small roots, cut rosette free with scissors
Habit: Height:  12" Spread:  12"
Something Special or Unique: Tolerates black walnut

Where to Grow: Full shade outdoors; eastern or western window, does not like direct sunlight
Soil Type: Well draining, low fertility, drought resistant
When to Divide: When a shoot has at least six leaves, cut it from the main plant with a clean scissors.  Then, place the stem in a glass of water and plant it in soil once roots have formed.  If there are leaves that have fallen off the plant, those can be laid on top the soil until they root.
Habit: Height: 2-12”, Spread: 4”, Clumping, rosette forming, groundcover
Something Special or Unique: Only likes to be watered about once per month, likes to thoroughly dry out between waterings.  Grows roots during the winter, mostly dormant during the summer.  Best to transplant in September after blooming.

When to Divide: Collect seeds in Fall for next year, and store at room temperature.
Habit: Height: 6"-12", Spread: 6", Clumping, occasionally reseeds
Something Special or Unique: Long blooming, pinch young plants for bushier growth.  Good in containers

Habit: Height:  12” (36” with flower stalk) Spread:  12” Clumping.
Something Special or Unique: Cut back after flowering for additional bloom. Unlike its invasive relatives, this species does not spread aggressively by self-sowing or rhizome

Soil Type: Average, medium, well-drained soil.  Tolerates full sun if the soils are kept moist.  Likes moist soils along streams, woodland gardens, or ponds.
When to Divide: Divide clumps early spring or summer
Habit: Height:  36" Spread:  12"
Something Special or Unique: Flowers are three inches across.  Likes to be grown near water.

When to Divide: Divide in spring.  Split on rhizomes.
Habit: Height:  12", 24" with flowers Spread:  18" Clumping habit
Something Special or Unique: Native plant, excellent cut flower.

Habit: Height:  24” (36” with flower stalk) Spread:  12”-18” Clumping.
Something Special or Unique: There are separate male and female plants.  Male flowers are showier than the females.  Transplant seedlings in August, after the summer heat. Tolerates black walnut trees.

Soil Type: Any soil, do not overwater (turns yellow)
When to Divide: Prefers not to be divided, easy to make cuttings and soak in water to start new plants
Habit: Height: 6-8”, Spread: 8”, Clumping
Long Lived or Short Lived: Rejuvenate by starting new plants from cuttings, or by lifting plant sprigs and adding leafy compost underneath.  Sprigs will grow new roots and rejuvenate plant
Something Special or Unique: Excellent for chicken and beef or vegetable casseroles. Has a citrus aftertaste. Use three to four sprigs per recipe. Can also be used to make tea. Plant grown organically

Soil Type: Any soil, do not overwater (turns yellow)
When to Divide: Prefers not to be divided, easy to make cuttings and soak in water to start new plants
Habit: Height: 6-8”, Spread: 8”, Clumping
Long Lived or Short Lived: Rejuvenate by starting new plants from cuttings, or by lifting plant sprigs and adding leafy compost underneath.  Sprigs will grow new roots and rejuvenate plant
Something Special or Unique: Excellent for chicken and beef or vegetable casseroles.  Use three to four sprigs per recipe.  Can also be used to make tea.  Plant grown organically.

Soil Type: Loamy, well-draining, average soil, will tolerates clay.  Does not tolerate water-logged soil in winter.
When to Divide: Do not divide; propagate by seed instead
Habit: Height:  24" Spread:  12"
Something Special or Unique: Native plant.  May wilt during drought, but will recover readily after rainfall.

When to Divide: Can be transplanted when less than 1 foot tall
Habit: Height: 4-6', Spread: 12”, Clumping, spreading by rosettes, but after many years
Maturity Rate: Three years until full height, might bloom first year, but definitely second year
Long Lived or Short Lived: Small first year, spends most of its energy setting roots
Something Special or Unique: Very difficult to grow from seed. Prefers afternoon shade from sun. May sag in full heat of summer, but recovers in the evening the first two years.  Monarch magnet.  Does not come up until June.  Mark so as not to accidentally dig it up.

When to Divide: Divide rosettes in spring every third year.
Habit: Height:  36" Spread:  12"
Something Special or Unique: Good mildew resistance, good cut flower. Genus name honors Saint Veronica who reportedly gave a handkerchief to Jesus so he could wipe sweat from his face on the way to Calvary, with some genus plants having markings that resemble the markings on the sacred handkerchief

Habit: Height: 24”, Spread: 24”, Clumping
Maturity Rate: Second year, plants will show true leaf color
Something Special or Unique: Good mildew resistance, good cut flower. Genus name honors Saint Veronica who reportedly gave a handkerchief to Jesus so he could wipe sweat from his face on the way to Calvary, with some genus plants having markings that resemble the markings on the sacred handkerchief

Soil Type: Average, medium to wet, well-drained soils
Habit: Height: 3'-4', 7' when blooming; Spread: 2'-3', Erect
Maturity Rate: Blooms second year.  They will double in size each year until full growth has been achieved in the third year.
Something Special or Unique: Can deadhead spent flower stalks to extend bloom period.  New foliage growth can be stimulated by cutting back plants to basal growth.  This may also promote a late summer or fall bloom.  Native to Eastern North America.
